issues.text: Whether on the facts and circumstances of this case there is a change in the persons carrying on the business within the meaning of section 8(1) of the Excess Profits Tax Act, 1940, with effect from 14th April, 1943, when the business, which had previously been carried on in partnership between two Dayabhaga Hindu undivided families, was carried on by a partnership between the separated male members of the two families?

anchor.surface_text: Whether on the facts and circumstances of this case ,there is a change in the persons carrying on the business within the meaning of section 8  1  of the Excess Profits Tax Act, 1940, with effect from 14th April, 1943, when the busi- ness, which had previously been carried on in partnership between two Dayabhaga Hindu undivided families, was car

issues.text: Whether the contention now advanced by the assessee that the firm was a partnership between the individual members prior to 14th April 1943 constitutes an entirely new case not open to the assessee?

anchor.surface_text: within the meaning of section 8 of the Excess Profits Tax Act. It appears to us that this is an entirely new case which is not open to the assessee to put forward. In the course of the assessment the Excess Profits Tax Officer found that previous to 14th April, 1943, the business was carried on by two Hindu undivided families,

issues.text: Whether a partnership agreement entered into by the kartas of two Hindu undivided families constitutes a partnership between the two families or between the kartas representing them?

anchor.surface_text: When two kartas of two Hindu undivided families enter into a partnership agreement the partnership is popularly described as one between the two Hindu undivided families but in the eye of the law it is a partnership between the two kartas and the other members of the families do not ipso facto become partners.

arguments.claim: There had been a change in the persons carrying on the business within the meaning of section 8 of the Excess Profits Tax Act with effect from 14th April 1943, so old deficiencies over Rs.84,000 cannot be carried forward, only Rs.12,804.

anchor.surface_text: The Excess Profits Tax Officer rejected this contention on the ground that there had been a change in the persons carrying on the business and the old business should be deemed to have been discontinued and a new business to have commenced within the meaning of section 8 of the Excess Profits Tax Act and carried over only Rs. 12,804.

arguments.court_reasoning: Supreme Court upholds the finding of change under s.8 based on facts of shift from two HUFs to eight individuals.

arguments.claim: The firm was originally a partnership of two HUFs represented by kartas, but from 17th June 1934 the sons individually became partners and firm remained so constituted, no change in persons under s.8 EPT Act.

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsels contention is that the firm was originally a partnership of two Hindu undivided families represented by their respective kartas Kshetra Mohan Sadhukhan and Sannyasi Charan Sadhukhan and that on and from the 17th June, 1934, the sons of Kshetra,

court_response_anchor.surface_text: f, as we hold, the assessee is number entitled to go behind the facts so found by the Appellate Tribunal in the statement of the case and as is implic

arguments.court_reasoning: Entirely new case not put forward before lower authorities, not open to assessee.

arguments.claim: Assessee's present contention is entirely new case not open, as previous authorities found business carried by two HUFs up to 13.4.1943 then by eight individuals post disruption.
There has been no variance in case; partnership by individual members of each HUF may be described as between two HUFs.
arguments.court_reasoning: HUF not juristic person for all purposes; partnership between kartas legally, members not ipso facto partners; no evidence of individual partnership before 14.4.1943.

arguments.claim: Partnership between two kartas of HUFs is legally between the kartas; other members do not ipso facto become partners; individual members can form partnership but inappropriate to call it between HUFs.

anchor.surface_text: When two kartas of two Hindu undivided families enter into a partnership agreement the partnership is popularly described as one between the two Hindu undivided families but in the eye of the law it is a partnership between the two kartas and the other members of the families do not ipso facto become partners.

arguments.claim: No evidence proves all members individually partners before 14.4.1943; documents do not support.

anchor.surface_text: There is, however, nothing to prevent the individual members of one Hindu undivided family from entering into a partnership with the individual members of another Hindu undivided family and in such a case it is a partnership between the individual members and it is wholly inappropriate to describe such a partnership as one between two Hindu undivided families. We need not pursue this matter further,

arguments.claim: Registration applications under s.26A, rules 2 & 3 show only two partners before 14.4.1943 (Kshetra Mohan Sadhukhan & sons and Bijan Kumar Sadhukhan & brothers), shares equal.

anchor.surface_text: Section 26-A permits an application to be made to the Income-tax Officer on behalf of any firm constituted under an instrument of partnership specifying the individual shares of the partners for registration for the purposes of the Indian Income-tax Act. Sub-section (2) of that section provides that the application shall be made by such person or persons,

arguments.claim: 1943 partnership deed between two parties (Gosta Behari Sadhukhan & Bros and Bijan Kumar Sadhukhan & Bros), clauses refer to 'either partner', equal 8 annas shares indicating two partners.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 2 of the Indian Income-tax Rules requires that such application shall be signed by all the partners personally. Rule 3 enjoins that the application shall be made in the form annexed to that rule. It appears that on the 19th October, 1943, an application was made on behalf of Kshetra Mohan Sadhukhan and sons and Bijan Kumar Sadhukhan and brothers for the renewal of the registration of the firm under section 26-A of the Indian Income-tax Act for the assessment for the Income-tax year 1942-43.

arguments.claim: 1944 deed recitals show firm reconstituted as eight partners from 14th April 1943 (1st Baisakh 1350 BS), inconsistent with prior eight partners.

anchor.surface_text: The instrument of partnership dated the 19th September, 1943, referred to in the application appears to be one made between Gosta Behari Sadhukhan and Bros. called the first party and Bijan Kumar Sadhukhan and Bros. called the second party. Clause 6 of that deed provided that the profits of the partnership should belong to the partners equally, i.e., eight-annas share each.

arguments.claim: Appellate Tribunal's statement of case binding on assessee, states up to 13.4.1943 partnership of two Dayabhaga HUFs, after eight members.

anchor.surface_text: It further appears that on the 28th December, 1944, another deed of partnership was drawn up. In this deed there are eight parties. Learned counsel for the appellant relies on the first four recitals as clearly indicating that even before the 13th April, 1943, the eight individual members of the two families carried on business in partnership.

arguments.claim: Income-tax returns up to 1943-44 show only two partners each 8 annas; from 1944-45 eight partners.

anchor.surface_text: The returns in the firms files up to 1943-44 also show only two partners-Kshetra Mohan Sadhukhan and sons and Sannyasi Charan Sadhukhan and sons-each having an eight annas share. It is from 1944-45 that eight partners are being shown.

arguments.claim: The referred question implies prior partnership of two HUFs (kartas), post-disruption eight individuals, giving rise to question of law under s.8.
Prior to reference, assessee contended business by two HUFs up to 13.4.1943 (four males each), then eight partnership; even suggested original adult members partners but accepted HUF position.
arguments.court_reasoning: Facts accepted but legal conclusion of no change under s.8 rejected.

holdings.text: There had been a change in the persons carrying on the business within the meaning of section 8 of the Excess Profits Tax Act with effect from 14th April, 1943.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Assessee bound by facts in Tribunal's statement of case showing shift from partnership of two HUFs (via kartas) to eight individuals post-disruption; no evidence or prior contention supports continuity of same persons.

holdings.text: The assessee's contention that the firm was a partnership between individual members from 17th June 1934 is an entirely new case not open to it.

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel's contention is that the firm was originally a partnership of two Hindu undivided families represented by their respective kartas Kshetra Mohan Sadhukhan and Sannyasi Charan Sadhukhan and that on and from the 17th June, 1934, the sons of Kshetra, It appears to us that this is an entirely new case which is not open to the assessee to put forward.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prior proceedings consistently treated business as carried by two HUFs up to 13.4.1943, then by eight individuals; new individual partnership theory first raised late, inconsistent with evidence and admissions.

holdings.text: A partnership agreement entered into by two kartas of Hindu undivided families is legally a partnership between the two kartas; other family members do not ipso facto become partners.

anchor.surface_text: When two kartas of two Hindu undivided families enter into a partnership agreement the partnership is popularly described as one between the two Hindu undivided families but in the eye of the law it is a partnership between the two kartas and the other members of the families do not ipso facto become partners.

holdings.reasoning_summary: HUF included in 'person' definition but not juristic person for all purposes; managed by karta; popular description differs from legal reality; individual members can partner separately but evidence lacking here.

holdings.text: A Hindu undivided family is included in the expression 'person' as defined in the Income-tax Act and Excess Profits Tax Act but is not a juristic person for all purposes.

anchor.surface_text: A Hindu undivided family is no doubt included in the expression person as defined in the Indian Income-tax Act as well as in the Excess Profits Tax Act but it is not a juristic person for all purposes.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Affairs managed by karta; distinction necessary for partnership analysis under tax law.

holdings.text: There is no evidence to prove that all members of the two families had individually become partners before 14th April, 1943.

anchor.surface_text: There is, however, nothing to prevent the individual members of one Hindu undivided family from entering into a partnership with the individual members of another Hindu undivided family and in such a case it is a partnership between the individual members and it is wholly inappropriate to describe such a partnership as one between two Hindu undivided families. We need not pursue this matter further, for in the case now before us there is no evidence whatever to prove that all the members of the two families had individually become partners in the business at any time before the 14th April, 1943.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Registration applications, partnership deeds, returns, and Tribunal statement all indicate two partners (HUFs/groups) pre-14.4.1943, eight post; recitals inconsistent with prior eight-partner claim.

holdings.text: The assessee is not entitled to go behind the facts found by the Appellate Tribunal in the statement of case.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Statement of case binding; implicit in referred question; alternative facts would preclude question of law.

Section 8 Excess Profits Tax Act, 1940 support

anchor.surface_text: If, as we hold, the assessee is number entitled to go behind the facts so found by the Appellate Tribunal in the statement of the case and as is implicit in the question itself, then there can be numberdoubt that there had been a change in the persons carrying on the business within the meaning of section 8 of the Excess Profits Tax Act and it has number been argued otherwise.

outcome.relief_summary: Assessee not entitled to go behind facts found by Tribunal; confirmed change in persons carrying on business under section 8 of Excess Profits Tax Act, denying carry forward of deficiencies from periods prior to 14th April 1943 except Rs. 12,804.

anchor.surface_text: When two kartas of two Hindu undivided families enter into a partnership agreement the partnership is popularly described as one between the two Hindu undivided families but in the eye of the law it is a partnership between the two kartas and the other members of the families do not ipso facto become partners.
